conversations.content:
¿Puedes hacer un resumen de esta transcripción de un audio?

56
00:02:56,320 --> 00:02:57,320
Astro.

57
00:02:57,440 --> 00:03:00,720
Astro es la nueva joya de la corona de desarrollo web.

58
00:03:00,840 --> 00:03:03,040
Bueno, al menos eso parece.

59
00:03:03,160 --> 00:03:07,560
Porque Astro tiene una nueva versión estable 1.0

60
00:03:07,680 --> 00:03:09,160
desde agosto de 2022.

61
00:03:09,160 --> 00:03:12,160
Y sigue, sigue publicando nuevas versiones.

62
00:03:12,280 --> 00:03:16,600
En el momento de grabar esto, estamos en la 1.4.

63
00:03:16,720 --> 00:03:20,040
Así que sigue avanzando pasito a pasito.

64
00:03:20,160 --> 00:03:21,720
Ahora vamos a descubrir

65
00:03:21,840 --> 00:03:23,840
algunas de sus principales características.

66
00:03:23,960 --> 00:03:25,920
Pero es gente muy lista,

67
00:03:26,040 --> 00:03:28,720
es gente lista la que está detrás de este desarrollo,

68
00:03:28,840 --> 00:03:31,000
porque su web ha ido evolucionando,

69
00:03:31,120 --> 00:03:32,840
a la vez que ha ido evolucionando también

70
00:03:32,960 --> 00:03:37,320
las capacidades que tiene de desarrollo.

71
00:03:37,320 --> 00:03:39,320
Y ahora, si tú entras en la web,

72
00:03:39,440 --> 00:03:43,160
tienes una captura que dice algo así como

73
00:03:43,280 --> 00:03:47,040
Rebuild my blog with Astro out of curiosity.

74
00:03:47,160 --> 00:03:48,280
Holly...

75
00:03:48,400 --> 00:03:52,360
Sale como si fueran unas palabrotas, unos tacos.

76
00:03:52,480 --> 00:03:56,640
O sea, alguien, bueno, en este caso el CEO de Pink Labs,

77
00:03:56,760 --> 00:03:57,880
un tal Cio,

78
00:03:58,000 --> 00:04:00,800
saca una gráfica y dice

79
00:04:00,920 --> 00:04:03,640
estoy reconstruyendo mi blog con Astro

80
00:04:03,760 --> 00:04:05,480
y me ha llevado esta sorpresa.

81
00:04:05,480 --> 00:04:07,480
Esto es una cosa espectacular.

82
00:04:07,600 --> 00:04:10,560
Una expresión de júbilo,

83
00:04:10,680 --> 00:04:13,240
a la vez que de casi ofensa.

84
00:04:13,360 --> 00:04:15,880
Y es que antes estaba hecho con NETJS,

85
00:04:16,000 --> 00:04:20,520
ahora mismo el principal enemigo a batir

86
00:04:20,640 --> 00:04:22,720
en este mundo de desarrollo web

87
00:04:22,840 --> 00:04:25,280
orientado hacia el Jamstack

88
00:04:25,400 --> 00:04:28,080
y tiene 138 kilobytes de carga,

89
00:04:28,200 --> 00:04:29,880
de carga de JavaScript.

90
00:04:30,000 --> 00:04:34,080
Y sale la comparativa con Astro y es un 7,6.

91
00:04:34,080 --> 00:04:35,920
Es muy poquito en comparación.

92
00:04:36,040 --> 00:04:37,600
Es una diferencia muy grande.

93
00:04:37,720 --> 00:04:39,920
Y esa es una de las principales,

94
00:04:40,040 --> 00:04:42,040
si no la principal, característica de Astro

95
00:04:42,160 --> 00:04:43,840
con respecto a la competencia,

96
00:04:43,960 --> 00:04:46,720
a lo que había cuando empezaron a desarrollar Astro,

97
00:04:46,840 --> 00:04:50,240
que es que quiere tener cero segment.

98
00:04:50,360 --> 00:04:54,320
O sea, no quiere llevar al cliente, al navegador,

99
00:04:54,440 --> 00:04:57,160
más JavaScript del que sea estrictamente necesario.

100
00:04:57,280 --> 00:04:58,960
O sea, HTML, por favor.

101
00:04:59,080 --> 00:05:02,080
Que el HTML es lo más rápido que se puede ejecutar en un navegador.

102
00:05:02,080 --> 00:05:04,360
Pone solo el JavaScript que necesite.

103
00:05:04,480 --> 00:05:06,560
Y además te invita,

104
00:05:06,680 --> 00:05:10,720
o vamos a ver cómo te invita

105
00:05:10,840 --> 00:05:13,600
o te permite tomar decisiones con respecto al JavaScript

106
00:05:13,720 --> 00:05:15,120
que tú quieres que cargue.

107
00:05:15,240 --> 00:05:17,000
O sea, te da mano en eso.

108
00:05:17,120 --> 00:05:19,480
Ahora tenemos ese detalle.

109
00:05:19,600 --> 00:05:21,640
Pero antes quiero pararme con algunos aspectos

110
00:05:21,760 --> 00:05:24,480
que no son tan claros cuando tú entras en la web,

111
00:05:24,600 --> 00:05:27,000
pero para mí sí es bastante significativo.

112
00:05:27,120 --> 00:05:30,080
Y hay una diferencia fundamental con respecto a...

113
00:05:30,080 --> 00:05:32,080
Yo diría que toda la competencia,

114
00:05:32,200 --> 00:05:34,440
toda, diría al 100% de la competencia,

115
00:05:34,560 --> 00:05:38,040
un porcentaje muy pequeño de los entornos de desarrollo

116
00:05:38,160 --> 00:05:41,160
tienen traducciones de la documentación al castellano.

117
00:05:41,280 --> 00:05:42,520
Y Astro sí que la tiene.

118
00:05:42,640 --> 00:05:45,920
Sí, hay algunos otros fringos que sí que tienen esa traducción,

119
00:05:46,040 --> 00:05:47,400
pero no es lo más habitual.

120
00:05:47,520 --> 00:05:50,480
Bueno, pues si te quieres sumergir en Astro en castellano,

121
00:05:50,600 --> 00:05:53,520
es uno de los idiomas en los que su documentación,

122
00:05:53,640 --> 00:05:54,920
no digo que está al completo,

123
00:05:55,040 --> 00:05:58,560
pero sí en un porcentaje no pequeño está traducida.

124
00:05:58,560 --> 00:06:03,360
Está traducida, así que es como un acercamiento mucho más liviano.

125
00:06:03,480 --> 00:06:05,720
Los conceptos se pueden entender mejor.

126
00:06:05,840 --> 00:06:07,680
Y es que Astro quiere explicártelo bien.

127
00:06:07,800 --> 00:06:09,880
A poco que profundices en la documentación,

128
00:06:10,000 --> 00:06:12,480
te darás cuenta que dice, nosotros lo hacemos así.

129
00:06:12,600 --> 00:06:14,560
Si lo quisieras hacer de esta otra forma,

130
00:06:14,680 --> 00:06:16,520
sería más complicado. O no funciona,

131
00:06:16,640 --> 00:06:19,160
porque nosotros hemos tomado esta decisión por ti.

132
00:06:19,280 --> 00:06:21,280
Recordar que Astro es un framework,

133
00:06:21,400 --> 00:06:23,360
por tanto, toman decisiones por ti,

134
00:06:23,480 --> 00:06:25,280
otra cosa es que a ti te gusten o no.

135
00:06:25,400 --> 00:06:27,720
Y hay otro aspecto que también está en el menú,

136
00:06:27,720 --> 00:06:28,880
que es la plantilla.

137
00:06:29,000 --> 00:06:31,680
Tiene un repositorio, a lo mejor no es muy grande,

138
00:06:31,800 --> 00:06:34,120
sobre todo si viene desde el mundo de WordPress,

139
00:06:34,240 --> 00:06:35,440
que es muy pequeño,

140
00:06:35,560 --> 00:06:39,600
o incluso de Wix o de Squarespace o de cualquier otro de estos lugares,

141
00:06:39,720 --> 00:06:41,760
pero en comparación con la competencia,

142
00:06:41,880 --> 00:06:45,400
también está mejor planteado, en el sentido de que se vea a la primera,

143
00:06:45,520 --> 00:06:48,800
que hay plantillas disponibles para que todo sea más llevadero.

144
00:06:48,920 --> 00:06:53,080
Al final, y esto es una reflexión no solamente para Astro,

145
00:06:53,200 --> 00:06:55,760
sino para todo tipo de desarrollo,

146
00:06:55,760 --> 00:06:59,240
si estás implicado en un desarrollo que quieres que la gente lo utilice,

147
00:06:59,360 --> 00:07:02,760
tienes que tomar buena nota de esto, hay que hacer labor de marketing,

148
00:07:02,880 --> 00:07:05,840
hay que presentar las cosas bonitas y, sobre todo, sencillas.

149
00:07:05,960 --> 00:07:09,160
Entonces, si alguien quiere probar Astro, como hacía este tal Cio,

150
00:07:09,280 --> 00:07:10,400
que estaba tan asombrado,

151
00:07:10,520 --> 00:07:14,160
necesitamos tener recursos que hagan que eso sea más fácil,

152
00:07:14,280 --> 00:07:17,760
y una de esas cosas que invitan es tener varias plantillas para elegir,

153
00:07:17,880 --> 00:07:19,560
aunque luego no utilicemos ninguna,

154
00:07:19,680 --> 00:07:22,240
o aunque luego digamos, bueno, todo lo programa un mono.

155
00:07:22,360 --> 00:07:24,320
Prefiero hacerlo yo.

156
00:07:24,320 --> 00:07:25,880
Mono con platillos, me refiero.

157
00:07:26,000 --> 00:07:29,080
No me gusta cómo está hecho esto, pero lo quiero hacer a mi manera.

158
00:07:29,200 --> 00:07:32,840
Pero la puerta de entrada se hace mucho más amplia.

159
00:07:32,960 --> 00:07:37,040
Astro tiene soporte nativo para Markdown, antes de que me preguntéis.

160
00:07:37,160 --> 00:07:40,120
O sea, ya directamente entiende este formato

161
00:07:40,240 --> 00:07:42,680
y también entiende el formato MDX.

162
00:07:42,800 --> 00:07:46,880
Y, bueno, como veremos ahora, tiene algunas características más.

163
00:07:47,000 --> 00:07:48,960
Sí quiero detenerme en otro aspecto,

164
00:07:49,080 --> 00:07:53,200
tampoco está reflejado aquí directamente en la página principal

165
00:07:53,200 --> 00:07:55,880
de Astro.Build,

166
00:07:56,000 --> 00:07:59,760
que si trabajáis con Visual Studio Code,

167
00:07:59,880 --> 00:08:01,640
que entiendo que de alguna forma

168
00:08:01,760 --> 00:08:04,400
prácticamente todo el mundo trabaja con esto, o con WebStorm,

169
00:08:04,520 --> 00:08:07,480
sabemos que hay más, hay más ideas en el mercado,

170
00:08:07,600 --> 00:08:11,560
pero parece que Visual Studio Code es ahora, que marca bastante la pauta,

171
00:08:11,680 --> 00:08:16,080
que sepáis que hay una extensión de Astro para Visual Studio Code

172
00:08:16,200 --> 00:08:18,360
que facilita el trabajo con él.

173
00:08:18,480 --> 00:08:22,160
Básicamente porque Astro propone su propia extensión,

174
00:08:22,160 --> 00:08:25,480
vais a quedar flipados con el nombre de la extensión de fichero

175
00:08:25,600 --> 00:08:28,480
que han propuesto, es.Astro.

176
00:08:28,600 --> 00:08:32,600
Y, bueno, pues nos va a permitir

177
00:08:32,720 --> 00:08:35,880
que Visual Studio Code o cualquier otro editor,

178
00:08:36,000 --> 00:08:39,320
si tiene extensiones, lo he mirado, pero es probable que sí que los tenga,

179
00:08:39,440 --> 00:08:41,400
porque al final quieren que más gente lo use.

180
00:08:41,520 --> 00:08:45,280
Bueno, pues que entienda esta extensión y entienda,

181
00:08:45,400 --> 00:08:49,720
comprenda cómo están construidos estos ficheros y para lo que sirven.

182
00:08:49,720 --> 00:08:53,680
Si te adelanto, porque puede que te estalle un poco la cabeza,

183
00:08:53,800 --> 00:08:56,960
que Astro lo que ha querido en esos ficheros

184
00:08:57,080 --> 00:09:01,800
es recoger un poco la experiencia que se va teniendo con el mundo del Jamstack,

185
00:09:01,920 --> 00:09:03,680
donde claramente hay dos...

186
00:09:03,800 --> 00:09:07,280
Todos los desarrollos se dividen en dos cosas.

187
00:09:07,400 --> 00:09:10,040
Una es lo que ve el usuario, o sea, lo que...

188
00:09:10,160 --> 00:09:13,720
o lo que se va a convertir luego en el HTML estático,

189
00:09:13,840 --> 00:09:18,000
y la otra es todo lo que necesitas, en este caso de JavaScript,

190
00:09:18,000 --> 00:09:20,560
pero en Hugo, por ejemplo, sería con Go, ¿no?

191
00:09:20,680 --> 00:09:24,160
Dependiendo del lenguaje de programación, en este estamos con JavaScript.

192
00:09:24,280 --> 00:09:28,360
Todo lo que vas a necesitar de JavaScript para que se puedan presentar los datos.

193
00:09:28,480 --> 00:09:30,600
Entonces, es como una división de markdown.

194
00:09:30,720 --> 00:09:33,160
No sé si habéis visto alguna vez el front matter.

195
00:09:33,280 --> 00:09:36,880
Front matter es esa forma que implantó Jekyll, si no me equivoco,

196
00:09:37,000 --> 00:09:41,600
para poder poner en la cabecera de un fichero markdown metadatos.

197
00:09:41,720 --> 00:09:45,680
Entonces, pones unas líneas, unos guiones, arriba y abajo,

198
00:09:45,680 --> 00:09:50,880
y eso es como que los editores de markdown todos entienden

199
00:09:51,000 --> 00:09:54,280
que ahí hay como una especie de metadatos donde tienes clave valor.

200
00:09:54,400 --> 00:09:56,400
En el caso de Astro, es con vitaminas,

201
00:09:56,520 --> 00:09:58,840
y además puedes poner ahí código JavaScript.

202
00:09:58,960 --> 00:09:59,960
Así de claro.

203
00:10:00,080 --> 00:10:02,120
Por ejemplo, tengo uno aquí delante.

204
00:10:02,240 --> 00:10:06,440
Let allPost igual a await Astro,

205
00:10:06,560 --> 00:10:09,240
es la librería global, punto, glob,

206
00:10:09,360 --> 00:10:12,000
y entonces hace una captura, o intenta hacer una captura

207
00:10:12,120 --> 00:10:14,880
de todos los ficheros markdown de la carpeta post.

208
00:10:14,880 --> 00:10:18,680
Para luego tener este allPost disponible en el resto del fichero.

209
00:10:18,800 --> 00:10:20,800
Así, así te lo cuento.

210
00:10:20,920 --> 00:10:24,040
Ya habrá tiempo de profundizar,

211
00:10:24,160 --> 00:10:27,200
te invito a hacerlo, nosotros lo vamos a hacer en el taller,

212
00:10:27,320 --> 00:10:31,840
pero al final van acoplando esas necesidades que se van viendo

213
00:10:31,960 --> 00:10:37,480
y que en otros sistemas similares o que intentan llegar al mismo sitio,

214
00:10:37,600 --> 00:10:41,680
sí se nota que, bueno, pues al final tú te tienes que buscar la vida,

215
00:10:41,800 --> 00:10:43,640
por ejemplo, para que leas los ficheros markdown.

216
00:10:43,640 --> 00:10:48,280
O esa combinación entre JavaScript, markdown, MDX,

217
00:10:48,400 --> 00:10:51,960
que parece ya muy simple al principio,

218
00:10:52,080 --> 00:10:55,080
pues al final tiene una carga de código que tienes que generar tú,

219
00:10:55,200 --> 00:10:57,880
que sí, lo puedes copiar y pegar de cualquier tutorial.

220
00:10:58,000 --> 00:11:00,200
Pero bueno, si al final lo que quieres es montar un blog,

221
00:11:00,320 --> 00:11:01,800
pues ¿por qué no te ahorran ese proceso?

222
00:11:01,920 --> 00:11:02,920
Es lo que piensa uno, ¿no?

223
00:11:03,040 --> 00:11:05,160
Dice, está muy bien, me aprendes, genial, estupendo,

224
00:11:05,280 --> 00:11:06,960
pero yo lo que quiero es ir al rano,

225
00:11:07,080 --> 00:11:09,640
quiero aquí ver cómo funcionan los enlaces,

226
00:11:09,760 --> 00:11:12,360
ver cómo el rendimiento de la web al final.

227
00:11:12,360 --> 00:11:15,960
Así que, bueno, estas son algunas de las cosas que me parecen llamativas

228
00:11:16,080 --> 00:11:19,240
antes de entrar a la chicha, al mogollón.

229
00:11:26,960 --> 00:11:29,240
En la web de Astro aparece enseguida

230
00:11:29,360 --> 00:11:31,880
cuáles son las características principales que tiene.

231
00:11:33,640 --> 00:11:36,520
Enfocado al contenido, esto es lo que acabo de decir,

232
00:11:36,640 --> 00:11:39,200
Astro fue diseñado para sitios web ricos en contenido,

233
00:11:39,320 --> 00:11:41,520
para que eso sea muy fácil de capturar.

234
00:11:41,520 --> 00:11:43,200
El servidor, lo primero.

235
00:11:43,320 --> 00:11:46,080
Los sitios se ejecutan más rápido si no tienen JavaScript.

236
00:11:46,200 --> 00:11:48,320
O sea, si partimos de un HTML más básico.

237
00:11:48,440 --> 00:11:50,720
Si el HTML ya está en el servidor generado.

238
00:11:50,840 --> 00:11:53,840
Rápido, por defecto, dicen,

239
00:11:53,960 --> 00:11:56,040
es imposible crear un sitio web lento con Astro.

240
00:11:56,160 --> 00:11:58,440
Bueno, déjalo en manos, déjalo en nuestras manos.

241
00:11:58,560 --> 00:12:00,240
Verás cómo somos capaces.

242
00:12:00,360 --> 00:12:02,120
Fácil de usar.

243
00:12:02,240 --> 00:12:05,240
Ellos dicen que no hace falta ser experto para desarrollar algo en Astro,

244
00:12:05,360 --> 00:12:07,240
es verdad que es bastante limpio, pero bueno,

245
00:12:07,360 --> 00:12:10,240
si realmente no has nunca aterrizado

246
00:12:10,240 --> 00:12:12,240
por el mundo del desarrollo web

247
00:12:12,360 --> 00:12:15,120
en el contexto del mundo del Jamstack,

248
00:12:15,240 --> 00:12:18,240
pues algunos conceptos son intercambiables con otros frameworks,

249
00:12:18,360 --> 00:12:20,360
pero hay que saber cuáles son.

250
00:12:20,480 --> 00:12:23,120
Y bueno, pues tiene más de 100 integraciones,

251
00:12:23,240 --> 00:12:25,320
luego hablaremos un poco más sobre ellas.

252
00:12:26,760 --> 00:12:30,760
Astro se basa en un tipo de arquitectura

253
00:12:30,880 --> 00:12:34,560
que se llama Islands Architecture, o sea, la arquitectura de las islas,

254
00:12:34,680 --> 00:12:38,280
y se han apropiado de ella, y aquí es donde viene,

255
00:12:38,280 --> 00:12:41,520
para mí, el hecho que pueda hacer que esta herramienta

256
00:12:41,640 --> 00:12:45,040
sea la joya de la corona, y hemos llegado a ese punto, ¿no?

257
00:12:45,160 --> 00:12:50,520
Porque lo que hace es que esas islas aisladas

258
00:12:50,640 --> 00:12:54,760
y que forman parte de nuestra arquitectura sean componentes.

259
00:12:54,880 --> 00:12:58,720
Entonces, en vez de tener una web,

260
00:12:58,840 --> 00:13:01,360
una single-page application, por ejemplo,

261
00:13:01,480 --> 00:13:03,800
o bueno, una aplicación de otro tipo,

262
00:13:03,920 --> 00:13:05,920
pero para que nos hagamos una idea, una SPA,

263
00:13:05,920 --> 00:13:09,720
donde todo va incrustado dentro de esa aplicación,

264
00:13:09,840 --> 00:13:13,120
pues lo que quiere, o lo que propone Astro,

265
00:13:13,240 --> 00:13:16,520
es que cada pieza, cada uno de esos componentes

266
00:13:16,640 --> 00:13:19,120
esté generado por JavaScript de forma independiente.

267
00:13:19,240 --> 00:13:23,240
O sea, en vez de tener un bundle con toda la aplicación, no.

268
00:13:23,360 --> 00:13:25,920
Tú dices, pues mira, yo aquí quiero poner un formulario,

269
00:13:26,040 --> 00:13:28,200
yo aquí quiero poner un contador,

270
00:13:28,320 --> 00:13:31,400
yo aquí, o sea, darle al botón, incrementar y incrementar,

271
00:13:31,520 --> 00:13:35,040
yo quiero aquí poner aquí un slider que hace algo específico,

272
00:13:35,040 --> 00:13:37,840
o otro bloque que sea un tracker

273
00:13:37,960 --> 00:13:41,160
de las últimas cotizaciones del blockchain,

274
00:13:41,280 --> 00:13:42,600
me lo invento, ¿no?

275
00:13:42,720 --> 00:13:46,240
Y que cada uno se comporte de forma diferente.

276
00:13:46,360 --> 00:13:49,520
O sea, como que estás creando pequeñas aplicaciones

277
00:13:49,640 --> 00:13:53,040
que luego vas a incrustar en ese punto Astro,

278
00:13:53,160 --> 00:13:56,920
en ese fichero global donde vas a meter esas piezas

279
00:13:57,040 --> 00:13:59,760
en el sitio adecuado, porque Astro te va a permitir,

280
00:13:59,880 --> 00:14:03,920
como os decía antes, en esa parte primera de ese fichero

281
00:14:03,920 --> 00:14:07,040
te va a permitir cargarlo, te va a permitir cargarlo.

282
00:14:07,160 --> 00:14:10,360
Y esta es la maravilla que hace que Astro sea compatible

283
00:14:10,480 --> 00:14:14,520
con React, con Vue, con Preact, con LIT,

284
00:14:14,640 --> 00:14:17,800
con AlpineJS, con Solid y con Svelte.

2.1	Hospital Play Services
Hospital play refers to activities and programs that are specifically designed for children who are hospitalized. These activities may include play, recreation, and education and are intended to provide a sense of normalcy and support the emotional well-being of hospitalized children. Hospital play programs may include activities such as arts and crafts, games, music, and storytelling and may be provided by trained play specialists, volunteers, or other members of the healthcare team. Hospital play programs are often tailored to the needs and interests of individual children, and may be adjusted to accommodate different age groups, developmental levels, and medical conditions. The goal of hospital play is to help children cope with the stress and uncertainty of being in the hospital and to provide them with enjoyable and engaging activities that can support their overall health and well-being.
Playright provides Hospital Play Services at six public hospitals, closely collaborating with healthcare professionals to provide psychosocial support to hospitalised children by using various PLAY interventions throughout their patient pathway. We support the child, their family and the medical team to strengthen holistic paediatric care and mitigate the stress and potential trauma that hospitalised and sick children may experience.

7.3	Limitations to Play in a Society
There are many ways in which countries or societies can violate or undermine the right of children to play. Some examples include:
1)	Lack of access to safe and accessible playgrounds and other recreational spaces: In some countries, children may not have access to safe and accessible playgrounds and other recreational spaces where they can engage in play and recreational activities. This can be due to a lack of funding for playgrounds, the absence of laws and regulations to protect children’s right to play, or other factors.
2)	Overly structured and adult-directed play: In some cases, children may be discouraged from engaging in free and imaginative play, and instead are expected to participate in overly structured and adult-directed activities. This can deprive children of the opportunity to develop their own interests and skills, and to explore and learn through play.
3)	High levels of violence and conflict: In some societies, high levels of violence and conflict can make it unsafe for children to play outside or engage in other forms of outdoor play. This can have a negative impact on children’s physical and emotional well-being, as well as their ability to engage in play and other recreational activities.
4)	Economic inequality: Economic inequality can also impact children’s ability to play and engage in recreational activities. For example, children from disadvantaged backgrounds may not have access to the same opportunities for play and recreation as children from more privileged families. This can create disparities in children’s access to play, and can have negative long-term effects on their development and well-being.
Overall, there are many ways in which countries and societies can violate or undermine children’s right to play. It is important for governments and other stakeholders to take steps to protect and promote this right, in order to support the overall development and well-being of children.

9	Safeguard Article 31 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child
According to the Article 31 of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC), all children have the right to rest and leisure, to engage in play and recreational activities appropriate to the age of the child, and to participate fully in cultural life and artistic life.
9.1.1	The Convention on the Rights of the Child
The Convention on the Rights of the Child is an international treaty that was adopted by the United Nations General Assembly on November 20, 1989. It sets out the rights that are to be afforded to children, including the right to education, healthcare, protection from violence and exploitation, and the right to participate in cultural and artistic activities. The Convention is the most widely ratified human rights treaty in history, with all but two member states of the United Nations have ratified it. It is also the only human rights treaty that provides for the participation of children in decision-making processes that affect them.
The Convention on the Rights of the Child recognises the right of every child to engage in play and leisure activities, which are essential for the child’s physical, mental, spiritual, moral, and social development. Article 31 of the Convention states that “State Parties recognise the right of the child to rest and leisure, to engage in play and recreational activities appropriate to the age of the child and to participate freely in cultural life and the arts.” The Convention also recognises the importance of play in promoting the physical and mental health of children and in fostering their creativity and imagination. It calls on States Parties to provide children with the necessary facilities and opportunities to engage in play and recreational activities and to take appropriate measures to protect children from harmful forms of work that may interfere with their right to play.
In addition to recognising the right of children to play, the Convention also emphasises the importance of play in children's overall development and well-being. Article 29 of the Convention states that education should be directed towards “the development of the child’s personality, talents and mental and physical abilities to their fullest potential.” Play is an essential part of this process, as it can help children develop their physical, social, emotional and cognitive skills.
9.1.2	The basis from the ten principles outlined in the European Association for Children in Hospital (EACH) Charter
1)	Children should only be admitted to the hospital if the care they need cannot be provided at home or daily.
2)	Children in the hospital have the right to have their parents or parent substitutes with them at all times.
3)	Parents should be offered accommodation and should not incur additional costs or suffer loss of income. They should be kept informed about ward routine and their active participation should be encouraged.
4)	Children and parents have the right to be informed in a manner appropriate to their age and understanding, and steps should be taken to mitigate physical and emotional stress.
5)	Children and parents have the right to informed participation in all decisions involving their health care, and every child should be protected from unnecessary medical treatment and investigation.
6)	Children should be cared for together with other children who have the same developmental needs, and there should be no age restrictions for visitors to children in the hospital.
7)	Children should have full opportunity for play, recreation, and education suited to their age and condition, and should be in an environment designed, furnished, staffed, and equipped to meet their needs.
8)	Children should be cared for by staff with the training and skills necessary to respond to their physical, emotional, and developmental needs.
9)	Continuity of care should be ensured by the team caring for children.
10)	Children should be treated with tact and understanding, and their privacy should be respected at all times.

25	What is Children’s Play?
Any behaviour or process initiated, controlled and structured by children themselves. Play is driven by intrinsic motivations and undertaken for its own sake, rather than as a means to an end. Play may take infinite forms but the key characteristics of play are fun, uncertainty, challenge, and flexibility.

As stated in the Article 31 of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child: “all children have the right to rest and leisure, to engage in play and recreational activities appropriate to the age of the child and to participate freely in cultural life and artistic life.”
26.2	Global Concern
The adverse effects of inadequate play on children’s growth are not only affecting Hong Kong, but also prevail around the globe. The worrisome phenomenon has aroused global concern. Hong Kong should not fall behind.
26.2.1	2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development
The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development is a plan of action adopted by the United Nations in 2015. It consists of 17 sustainable development goals (SDGs) that aim to end poverty, protect the planet, and ensure prosperity for all people.
Some of the goals and targets that relate to children include:

2)	Goal 4: Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all. Target 4.1: Ensure that by 2030 all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care, and preprimary education so that they are ready for primary education.

27	Benefits of Play
A lot of research conducted in the past pointed out the benefits and values of play, including physical development, sociability and communication, cognitive thinking, incubating creativity, expressing emotions, nurturing concentration ability, problem solving, self-understanding, taking challenges, building self-confidence etc. As explained in detail in the thesis issued by the International Play Association in 2014, play is crucial in the development and growth of children. The thesis titled “Power of Play” issued by the American Academy of Pediatrics in 2018 also restated the importance of play, and even advised doctors to use “play” as a new prescription to promote children’s health.
27.1	The Power of Play thesis
The “Power of Play” thesis provides guidance to doctors on how to incorporate play into their practice and promote play in children’s daily lives. The thesis recommends that doctors:
1)	Educate parents and caregivers about the importance of play and the benefits it provides for children’s development and well-being.
2)	Encourage parents and caregivers to create opportunities for play in their child’s daily routine, including structured play activities and unstructured playtime.
3)	Help parents and caregivers to understand the different types of play and their benefits, such as imaginative play, physical play, and social play.
4)	Advise parents and caregivers to limit the use of screen time and other sedentary activities, and to encourage their children to engage in regular physical activity through play.
5)	Provide guidance to parents and caregivers on how to support their child’s play, including how to facilitate and encourage play, how to provide a safe play environment, and how to respond to their child’s play.
6)	Encourage parents and caregivers to play with their children, as this can help to strengthen the parent-child bond and provide opportunities for bonding and social interaction.

The thesis also recommends that doctors:
1)	Use play as a therapeutic tool to help children cope with stress, anxiety, and other mental health issues.
2)	Use play to help children develop their cognitive, physical, emotional, and social skills.
3)	Use play as a way to diagnose and assess children’s development, behavior, and mental health.
4)	Use play as a way to prescribe and promote healthy habits and behaviors, such as regular physical activity and healthy eating.
Professional Work
28	Play & Playwork
For the healthy growth of children, play should be an integral part of children’s life at school, at home and in the community. To achieve the above, play opportunities and adults’ support are crucial. Playright’s Play and Playwork hub strives to create play and satisfy the needs of every child through a variety of demonstrations and empowerment, including organising activities, arrangement of professional training, provision of play resources and operation of play spaces.
In future decade, we aim to extend free play time from kindergartens to all early childhood settings, special schools and primary schools, and to make child-led community play spaces available in 18 districts all over Hong Kong.
28.1	Play in School
Children start their schooling at an early age. Hence, it would be ideal if play could be integrated into their school life. Starting from 2011, we have introduced play in special schools. Through demonstration, training for teachers, on-site consultancy and de-briefing and parents’ talks, we have helped teachers to arrange free play on their own. In response to the requirement that “half-day and whole-day kindergartens should arrange children to participate in free play lasting for no less than 30 and 50 minutes respectively every day” stipulated in the “Kindergarten Education Curriculum Guide” issued by the Education Bureau in early 2017, we seized the opportunity to launch the “Seed School Training Programme”. With different characteristics of schools in mind, we arranged demonstration, training and on-site consultancy and de-briefing to equip school teachers master the skills of arranging free play. We hope that the concept of “Seed Schools” will be expanded so that free play time can be extended from kindergartens to all pre-school settings, special schools and primary schools.
28.2	Play in Community & Outreach
Children’s holistic growth is related to the community. If people in the communities accept children’s play, support play and even create play, children can grow more healthily. Hence, we began the trial of community play in 2012. In 2013, we launched a 3-year project titled “The Playbourhood” and implemented in different phases in Tin Shui Wai, Wong Tai Sin, Sau Mau Ping and Tseung Kwan O. 
28.2.1	Play in Neighborhood
In 2017, we introduced another 3-year project named “Playful Community League” which was implemented in Tai Po, Lai Chi Kok, Central Western District and Kwai Tsing. We aim to motivate the residents, community groups and organisations to join and collaborate their efforts to build up an atmosphere of free play and to establish a regular play space in the community parks so as to create a playful community for children.
We hope that there will be a child-led play space in every community and this concept can blossom in all 18 districts in Hong Kong so that every little neighbour can benefit from play.

29	Hospital Play
Play is children’s basic need. Even when they are sick, their natural instinct does not change. Our Hospital Play, which commenced in 1994, is targeted at child patients. The service helps children to engage in play during their pathway of fighting an illness and being hospitalised, as well as to understand medical procedures, the environment and what is happening in their lives intellectually and psychologically. Apart from looking after children, we also support their families and partner with medical professionals to develop and promote hospital play and conduct research so as to strengthen holistic paediatric care.
In future decade, we aim to make every hospital with a Paediatric department include a hospital play service, thus letting play become an integral part of the growth of every sick child.
29.1	Medial Collaboration
Currently, Playright provides a regular honorary hospital play service at 6 public hospitals in 5 clusters. The hospitals receiving our service include the Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital of the Hong Kong East cluster, the Caritas Medical Centre and the Princess Margaret Hospital of the Kowloon West cluster, the Tseung Kwan O Hospital of the Kowloon East cluster, the Hong Kong Children’s Hospital of the Kowloon Central Cluster, as well as the Prince of Wales Hospital of the New Territories East cluster.
For the benefit of sick children, our hospital play specialists are stationed at hospitals every weekday and work closely with the other professionals including doctors, nurses, specialist medical staff and ward staff. In view of different treatments and different illnesses, the hospital play specialists create partnerships with the medical team to design a tailor-made hospital play plan for the sick children. Apart from the daily hospital play, the hospital play specialists have also co-operated with hospitals in response to the outbreak of SARS, Human Swine flu and lead-in-drinking-water in housing estates with regard to calming children through routine medical procedures such as blood taking and/or being put in isolation.
29.1.1	Preparation Play
We prepare children psychologically for upcoming medical procedures and treatments in order to reduce their stress and anxiety, including chemotherapy, hemodialysis, CT scan, blood taking and many others.
29.1.2	Distraction Play
We help children cope with pain and anxiety during medical procedures by distracting them with interesting games and toys.
29.1.3	Medical Play
Through medical toys, we provide children with opportunities to learn some medical knowledge and express their feelings towards their illness.
29.1.4	Therapeutic Play
We provide tailor-made play services to children and teenagers who are suffering from behavioral problems, eating disorders or child abuse for helping them to build up a more healthy and happy life in the future.
29.1.5	Developmental Play
We provide appropriate play activities for children to have optimum psychobgical and psychosocial development during hospitalisation.

33	Intervention Research on Children’s Free Play: Parents’ Perspectives 2021
33.1	Executive Summary
This study was undertaken in Hong Kong, in which the influence of the COVID-19 pandemic on people from all walks of life was evident. Various preventive measures were enforced, including the closure of many outdoor playgrounds and the suspension of face-to-face contact in schools. These preventive measures impacted children because of the restrictions on their use of public facilities for leisure activities.
Playright has always promoted free play in Hong Kong and had considerable concerns about the impact of the pandemic on children’s play. In this regard, Playright developed a free play protocol that was implemented either in self-organised programmes or in partnership with some kindergartens. Against this backdrop, this study examined the evidence-based outcomes of the protocol.
33.2	Research Objectives
The study aimed to examine parents’ perceptions of free play, parents’ engagement with their child in free play, and the possible influences of free play on parents’ mental health and parent-child relationships. Specifically, this study aimed to address research areas, including
1)	Parents’ perceptions of free play;
2)	Parents’ engagement in free play with their children;
3)	Barriers and difficulties faced by parents in engaging in free play with their children;
4)	The outcomes of free play, specifically on parent-child relationships and parents’ mental health.
33.3	Methodology
Part A of the study investigated the effectiveness of the PLAYBAG intervention protocol in three kindergartens. Target participants were parents who participated in the PLAYBAG programme in these three kindergartens. A mixed-methods approach was adopted to collect quantitative pre- and post-intervention data by questionnaires capturing parents’ perceptions of free play, their engagement with their children in free play, their mental health and their relationship with their children. Parents participated in focus group interviews to inform understanding of their engagement in free play with their children. Thematic analysis was employed to analyse the data from the focus group interviews.
Part B comprised a cross-sectional and quantitative investigation of parents’ perceptions of free play, their participation in free play with their children and their relationships with their children. Target respondents were parents involved in the ‘Playright Home Play Box’ and ‘Medical Play Experiential Box’ activities organised by Playright between April 2020 and May 2021.
33.4	Findings
Part A confirmed the evidence-based effectiveness of the PLAYBAG intervention protocol in terms of enhancing parents’ perceptions of free play, fostering positive parent-child relationships, and promoting parents’ mental health. In addition, more than 80% of parents agreed that their child spent more time on PLAYBAG and other free play activities at home and that they had increased confidence engaging in free play activities with their child.
Regarding the intersection of parents’ perceptions of play and socio-demographic background, Part B found that mothers were more inclined to endorse play freedom than fathers. Fathers embraced play safety more than mothers. Compared to parents with a tertiary or university education, parents with senior high school or below education were more inclined to endorse parental rules, play safety, gender stereotyping, and the importance of structured play and were less inclined to support imaginative play. In terms of play freedom, no significant difference was evident between parents with different levels of education. Parents in full-time employment were less inclined to support parental rules in play. Compared with parents of primary school-aged children, parents of children in kindergarten were less focused on parental rules when engaging in free play with their children. Regarding living space, parents living in confined accommodations were much concerned about safety problems when engaging in free play with their children.
This study also examined the intersection of parents’ perceptions of play and parent-child relationships. Closer parent-child interaction and more positive parent-child relationships as a whole were evident among parents who endorsed play freedom and imaginative play. More conflict in parent-child relationships was observed when parents emphasised play safety and gender stereotyping in children’s play. Investigation of the relationship between parental perceptions of play and the average time spent in free play revealed that parents who endorsed play freedom, imaginative play and children’s choices allowed their children to spend more time on free play.
This study found that children spent more time in free play with their mother than their father. It identified parents’ long working hours, children’s rest schedules, and limited indoor space as the three most important barriers impacting parents’ engagement in free play with their children. Parents considered female children’s rest schedules the most influential factor affecting free play. Parents of primary school-age children considered the amount of homework as the most influential factor in free play. Parents who emphasised play safety were more likely to consider limited indoor space and difficulty balancing responsibilities as factors influencing their engagement in free play with their children. Moreover, parents who embraced play safety were more inclined to impose rules and regulations on their children in free play. This posed a dilemma for parents in balancing the roles of discipline enforcer and playmate.
The focus group interviews provided a fruitful insight into understanding parents’ participation in free play with their children. Four essential elements were identified that facilitated meaningful interaction between parents and children in free play: 1) an egalitarian and non-judgmental attitude, 2) the quality of encounters with children in free play, 3) discoveries about their children, and 4) sustaining new meanings of their children’s identity.
33.5	Recommendations
The results of this study generated the following recommendations:
1)	Enhancement of the PLAYBAG intervention protocol to address the specific needs of parents from different socio-economic backgrounds. For instance, parents’ sessions for fathers, parents with full-time employment, parents with children from different age groups etc. Contents of parents’ sessions could provide more solutions to tackle the dilemmas faced by parents when engaging in free play with their children. More scenarios regarding possible ways to use the unstructured play materials in free play could be added in the parents’ sessions.
2)	Parental education on free play should be widely implemented in kindergartens and schools through collaboration among different stakeholders in the community, echoing a recent proposal, “Curriculum Framework on Parent Education (Kindergarten)” published by the Education Bureau. Parental education on children’s free play might include principles and benefits of free play, effective ways to engage children in free play, creating quality free play time in families, and co-parenting perspective of engaging fathers and mothers in free play.
3)	Promotion of free play to the general public, in particular, to generate an understanding of the importance of free play, and positive outcomes regarding the enhancement of mental health and parent-child relationships, should be emphasised in community education programmes. The pandemic seriously affected parents’ and children’s mental health and well-being, and free play in the home and school environment helped relieve stress and anxiety and enhance family bonding.
4. The barriers to children’s engagement in free play should be removed. Home-school collaboration needs to be strengthened to enhance parents’ and children’s creativity, participation, and collaboration in free play activities. Teachers’ training regarding free play implementation in school settings are recommended. Policies to streamline the amount of homework given to children and the development of a child-friendly free play school environment are advocated.
5. Creating an innovative child-friendly free play environment should be promoted through collaboration between different stakeholders in the community. Apart from improving the designated playgrounds provided by Housing Authority and Leisure and Cultural Services Department, different community stakeholders could work together to create various doorstep, indoor or outdoor play space for children and their parents to have free play in safe environment.
6. Last but not least, consideration should be given to empowering children’s voices to cocreate a free play environment. Different models or tools for children’s participation should be adopted to fit various needs of children. Moreover, trainings are also required for the adults to listen, collect and respect children’s voices in regard to those child-related issues.
34	Research 2014 on the effectiveness of therapeutic play in minimising anxiety and negative emotions of hospitalised children
34.1	Project Summary
Objective: To test the effectiveness of a therapeutic play intervention in minimising the anxiety levels and negative emotions of hospitalised Hong Kong Chinese children.
Methods: A non-equivalent control group pretest–posttest, between subjects design was conducted in the two largest acute-care public hospitals in Hong Kong. Chinese children (3-12 years of age; n = 304) admitted for treatment in these two hospitals were invited to participate in the study. Of the 304 subjects, 154 received the therapeutic play intervention and 150 received usual care.
Results: Children who received the therapeutic play intervention reported less negative emotional behaviour and lower levels of anxiety compared to those who received usual care only during hospitalisation.
Conclusion: The study provides empirical evidence to support the effectiveness of therapeutic play interventions in minimising the anxiety and negative emotions of hospitalised children.
Practice implications: The findings heighten the awareness of the importance of integrating therapeutic play as an essential component of holistic and high-quality care to ease the psychological burden of hospitalised children. It is crucial to have more hospital play specialists to facilitate the integration of therapeutic play into routine care for hospitalised children.
34.2	Introduction
Hospitalisation can be a stressful and threatening experience for everyone, especially for children [1]. The physiological and psychological health needs of children are typically different from those of adults. Children are more vulnerable to the stress of hospitalisation because of their cognitive limitations, lack of self-control, dependence on others, and limited experience and knowledge of the healthcare system [2]. A lack of understanding about the upcoming procedures, unfamiliarity with the hospital environment, and failure to understand the reasons for hospitalisation can add to their anxiety, fear, anger, uncertainty, and feelings of helplessness. Among these negative responses, anxiety is the most commonly reported. Excessive anxiety can be detrimental to children’s physical and psychological health. Anxiety also hinders children’s ability to cope with medical treatment, and encourages negative and uncooperative behaviour toward healthcare. The link between anxiety and negative outcomes suggests that reducing children’s anxiety during periods of hospitalisation could promote better recovery.
Play has been widely used in many Western countries to alleviate the stress experienced by paediatric patients and their families during hospitalisation. Erikson and Piaget observed that play is essential for children’s normal growth and development, as it provides an expression of their understanding about the world and an opportunity for them to develop mastery of self and the environment. Indeed, play has long been recognised as a vital element of psychological interventions to help children withstand the stress of hospitalisation.
Florence Erickson, a pioneer in the study of play for hospitalised children, emphasised that play is an integral part of children’s lives. Erickson conducted a study to explore the reactions of children to hospital experience and confirmed that children who were given an opportunity to play with clinical equipment were better able to express their feelings about their hospital experiences. She demonstrated the benefits of using play interviews and dolls to prepare hospitalised children for intrusive medical procedures.
34.3	Play Therapy and Therapeutic Play
According to psychoanalytic theory, play therapy is part of child psychiatry and is similar in
nature to psychotherapy for adults. Erikson described how play therapy benefited children who had experienced trauma or who had behavioural disorders. Over the past decades, play therapy has been widely used by psychotherapists to help children work through their problems during psychotherapy.
Therapeutic play, in contrast, is a set of structured activities appropriately designed for children’s levels of psychosocial and cognitive development and health-related issues to psychologically prepare them for hospitalisation. The past decade has seen an increase in the use of therapeutic play interventions to help children cope with the stress of hospitalisation. Regrettably, the majority of studies that have studied activities for hospitalised children have been in the form of case studies based on theories and clinical observations. There is a lack of empirical evidence to accurately determine the clinical effectiveness of the therapeutic play. The results of a randomised controlled trial to examine the effects of a therapeutic play intervention on the outcomes of children undergoing day surgery showed that those who received the intervention reported lower state anxiety scores and exhibited fewer instances of negative emotional behaviour in pre- and postoperative periods. Nevertheless, the implications of this study were limited because the children only received minor elective surgeries and did not stay in hospital overnight. Therefore, more empirical evidence is needed to determine the effectiveness of therapeutic play in reducing the anxiety levels and negative emotions of hospitalised children. 
It is well documented that Hong Kong Chinese people are influenced by the philosophy of Confucianism, which emphasises balance and harmony achieved through the concepts of chung and yung in everyday life. Under the influence of this philosophy, disease is regarded as arising from ‘bad spirits’, and it is believed that exercise will only aggravate the disease and violate the rule of harmony. In this cultural context, hospitalised children are often advised by their parents or even healthcare professionals to take more rest and not to engage in any energy-consuming activities, including play activities. Furthermore, as many Chinese parents and some healthcare staff traditionally view play as less important than physiological care or medical treatment, it is not clear whether therapeutic play is an appropriate and feasible psychological intervention for hospitalised children in the Hong Kong Chinese context. Given these issues, this study aimed to test the effectiveness of a therapeutic play intervention in minimising the anxiety and negative emotions of hospitalised Hong Kong Chinese children. Specifically, the focus was on assessing the potential of implementing the therapeutic play intervention for hospitalised children in Hong Kong clinical settings.
34.4	Theoretical framework
This study was guided by Lazarus and Folkman’s [13] theory of cognitive appraisal, stress and coping, which is one of the most commonly applied theoretical perspectives on how people cope with stress. This transactional model is also the most frequently applied model in research on children [2, 12, 14]. According to Lazarus and Folkman [13], stress is defined as a dynamic ongoing relationship between a person and his or her environment, and cognitive appraisal is the process by which an individual evaluates or judges the meaning of a potentially stressful event and its significance to his or her well-being. 
It is well documented that hospitalisation can be a highly stressful and anxiety-provoking experience for children and can have profound effects on them. Lazarus and Folkman postulated that individuals’ evaluations are influenced by their perceptions of control over a potential threat. Previous studies have shown that a lack of control over the physical setting of the hospital and upcoming medical procedures is a major source of stress, which may cause considerable anxiety for hospitalised children. We reasoned that if children believe they have adequate control over a potential threat, they will experience less anxiety and report fewer negative emotions. Therefore, a primary goal of the therapeutic play intervention was to assist children in regaining a sense of self-control. We anticipated that conducting the intervention in the hospital would increase children’s familiarity with the hospital environment and thereby enhance their sense of personal control. We also surmised that through participating in play activities, children would develop their interpersonal and communication skills, self-care and social and creative abilities. Children were not only encouraged to have fun, but were also taught to desensitise to potentially stressful situations and to instil a sense of control over the situation in which they were involved. The intervention allowed the children to practise medical or nursing routines through play and interact with the environment in an active and non-threatening rather than passive way. 
34.5	Methods 
34.5.1	Design and sample 
To examine the effects of the therapeutic play intervention, we used a non-equivalent control group pretest–posttest, between-subjects design. The study was carried out in the two largest acute-care public hospitals in Hong Kong, with one hospital assigned as the “control” and the other as the “experimental” hospital. The two hospitals have similar paediatric specialities, settings, and medical and nursing care. Chinese children admitted for treatment in these two acute public hospitals and who met the inclusion criteria were invited to participate in the study. The inclusion criteria for eligible children were (1) aged between 3 and 12 years, (2) able to speak Cantonese, and (3) required to stay in hospital for at least three consecutive days. Children with cognitive and learning difficulties identified from their medical records were excluded. 
The sample size was calculated to ensure sufficient power to detect differences between the groups. With reference to the previous study that examined the effects of therapeutic play intervention on the outcomes of children undergoing day surgery, we predicted a medium effect size for the differences between the two groups. To predict this effect size at a 5% significance level (p < 0.05) and power of 0.80, we calculated that 64 subjects would be required in each group. We allowed for a potential attrition rate of 15%, which is common in experimental designs. Accordingly, 11 additional participants per group were needed to cover the attrition, giving a total sample size of 150. However, according to Piaget, children aged between 3-7 and 8-12 are at the preoperational and concrete operational stages of development, respectively. Because children’s cognitive development is linked to their age, different methods of assessment were used for the two age groups. Therefore, the data analyses were performed separately for the two age groups, 3-7 and 8-12 years. Hence, we aimed to recruit at least 300 (150 in each age group) subjects in this study. 
34.6	Intervention 
The control group participants received usual medical and nursing care, while the experimental group participants received around 30 minutes of therapeutic play intervention, which hospital play specialists conducted on each weekday. The content of the therapeutic play included a variety of structured and non-structured activities. The hospital play specialists selected suitable activities in accordance with the children’s sex, age, ability, type of illness, and general condition. 34.7	Measures
34.7.1	Demographic data sheet 
A demographic data sheet constructed for this study was used to record the children’s demographic and clinical characteristics, including their age, gender, diagnosis, and number of hospital admissions.
34.7.2	Anxiety levels of children aged between 3 and 7 years 10 
The visual analogue scale (VAS) was used to assess children’s anxiety levels. The VAS consists of a 10 cm horizontal line on a piece of paper, with different facial expressions supplemented by the words ‘not worried’ at one end and ‘very worried’ at the other. Higher scores indicate higher levels of anxiety. Children aged between 5 and 7 used a movable indicator to show their levels of anxiety. However, as children aged 3-4 might have limited verbal expression and cognitive capacities and could be confused by the scale, this age group was assessed by asking the parents to rate their child’s anxiety level. The VAS is one of the most widely used measurement tools because it is easy to administer, simple for children to understand, and is a valid method for measuring subjective feelings [17]. One of the biggest advantages of using the VAS is that it is not affected by the limited test-taking ability of younger children. Previous studies have found the VAS to be a reliable, valid, and sensitive measure of individual subjective feelings. 
34.7.3	Anxiety levels of children aged between 8 and 12 years 
The anxiety levels of children in this age group were measured using the short form of the Chinese version of the State Anxiety Scale for Children (CSAS-C). The short form of the CSAS-C consists of 10 items scored from 1 to 3, with total possible scores ranging from 10 to 30. Higher scores indicate greater anxiety. The psychometric properties of the short form of the CSAS-C have been empirically tested [20] and show adequate internal consistency reliability, good concurrent validity, and excellent construct validity. The results of a confirmatory factor analysis added further evidence of the construct validity of the short form of the CSAS-C.
34.8	Children’s Emotional Manifestation Scale (CEMS) 
The emotional responses of the hospitalised children were documented using the CEMS. The CEMS score is obtained by reviewing the descriptions of behaviour in each category and selecting the number that most closely represents the child’s observed behaviour. Each category is scored from 1 to 5, with summed scores between 5 and 25. Higher scores indicate more negative emotional behaviour. The psychometric properties of the CEMS have been empirically tested and show adequate internal consistency reliability, good inter-rater reliability, and excellent construct validity. 
34.8.1	Process evaluation 
To assess the implementation potential of the therapeutic play intervention, a short one-to-one semi-structured interview was conducted with five children aged between 8 and 12 and with the parents of five children aged between 3 and 12, randomly selected from the experimental group. Children and parents were interviewed separately. They were asked to express their views on the acceptability and suitability of the therapeutic play intervention. In addition, to examine whether it is feasible to implement the therapeutic play intervention in clinical settings and whether it is acceptable to healthcare providers, five nurses working in the paediatric units delivering the therapeutic play intervention were randomly invited for a short interview at the end of the study. All of the interviews were conducted by a full-time research assistant with considerable experience of conducting qualitative interviews. The interviews were taped-recorded.
34.9	Data collection procedures
Approval for the study was obtained from the hospital ethics committees. Written consent was obtained from the parents after they were told the purpose of the study. The children and their parents were informed that they had the right to withdraw from the study at any time and were assured of the confidentiality of their data.
After signing the consent form, a research assistant collected the demographic data from the parents and from the children’s medical records. The children’s baseline anxiety levels were also assessed and documented. For the experimental group, the therapeutic play intervention started after the baseline data had been collected. A research assistant observed the emotional behaviour of each child for two consecutive days (4 hours consecutively per day). At the end of the two days’ observation, a research assistant documented the child’s overall emotional behaviour using the CEMS. The child’s anxiety levels were reassessed and documented. Semi-structured interviews were conducted with selected children and their parents. Once the data collection for all participants was completed, a short interview was conducted with selected nurses working in the paediatric units where the therapeutic play intervention was implemented.
34.10	Data analysis 
The Statistical Package for Social Science (SPSS: Version 19; SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA) for Windows was used for the data analysis. Descriptive statistics were used to calculate the means, standard deviations, and ranges of the scores on the various scales. The homogeneity of the experimental and control groups was assessed using inferential statistics (independent t-test and x2). The interrelationships among the scores on the different scales and the demographic variables were investigated using the Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient. Differences in the mean scores on the CEMS and the children’s anxiety levels between the two intervention groups were assessed by an independent t-test and mixed between-within subjects ANOVA, respectively. Multiple regression analysis was performed to examine the effects of participants’ demographic and clinical characteristics on the outcome measures.
Content analysis was adopted to analyse the semi-structured interviews. According to Weber (1990), it is one of the most objective and systematic approaches used for qualitative data analysis. With reference to the study protocol, the recordings were fully transcribed verbatim immediately after the interviews. Two research students who were not involved in data collection helped to identify different themes by examining the transcriptions line by line. All these identified themes would be further summarised as codes according to their similarities and differences. Any dialogue relevant to the codes was translated into English for reporting. The research team members resolved disagreements of the analysis during their meetings.

34.18	Discussion 
The findings of this study suggest that the Hong Kong Chinese children experienced considerable anxiety on admission to hospital. The results are consistent with previous studies that found that hospitalised children experienced different degrees of sadness, unhappiness and worry. In comparison with previous studies that have used the same scale to measure the anxiety of Hong Kong Chinese children of a similar age, the anxiety scores of children on admission to hospital in this study were similar to those of children immediately before undergoing surgery, but higher than those of school children in the pre-academic examination period. The results also showed a high positive correlation between the CSAS-C and CEMS. The findings concur with those of a previous study, in which children with high anxiety levels in the immediate pre-operative period had more negative emotional responses during the procedure for anaesthesia induction. The findings provide further evidence that anxiety hinders children’s ability to cope with hospitalisation and medical treatment, and increases negative and uncooperative behaviour toward healthcare. 
There is an assumption that the number of hospital admissions a child experiences strongly affects his or her anxiety levels and emotional responses. Nevertheless, the multiple regression analysis results did not find statistically significant effects for the number of hospital admissions on children’s outcomes in this study. The findings suggest that hospitalisation is a stressful and threatening experience for children, regardless of whether they have had previous hospital admission experience. 
The overall results support the effectiveness of therapeutic play in minimising the anxiety levels and negative emotions of Hong Kong Chinese children who have been hospitalised. Indeed, providing therapeutic play for children during hospitalisation has particular advantages because illness and its accompanying stress and physical restriction interrupt natural play and socialisation, which are essential for children’s normal growth and development. Most importantly, involvement in play activities during hospitalisation can improve children’s coping skills and decrease their stress, eventually leading to better psychosocial adjustment to their illness and hospitalisation. 
34.18.1	Implementation potential of therapeutic play in clinical settings 
Although the overall results provide evidence that the therapeutic play intervention was effective in minimising children’s anxiety and negative emotions during hospitalisation, it is crucial to ensure that the intervention can be implemented in clinical practice. To ensure the children were able to engage in play activities, the time of implementation was flexible and the sessions were repeated at different times of the day. Participants were invited to join the play activities when they were not occupied by any medical treatments or physiological care. Therefore, it would be feasible for the healthcare system to consider incorporating therapeutic play as a routine psychological preparation for children undergoing hospitalisation. 
Most of the interviewed children reported that the therapeutic play intervention helped relieve their anxiety because they better understand their illness and the medical procedures. Most of the children were pleased to know that most of the medical or nursing procedures would not cause them any pain and would be well controlled. Most importantly, the children enjoyed the therapeutic play in the hospital and found the activities fun and interesting. 
Although Chinese parents have traditionally viewed play as less critical for hospitalised children than physiological care or medical treatment, most of the parents in the experimental group appreciated the availability of play activities within the hospital. Indeed, a previous study conducted in Hong Kong showed that parents were reassured by watching their children participate in play activities and interact with children. 
All of the nurses in the interview commented that the therapeutic play effectively reduced the children’s negative emotions during hospitalisation, which gave them time to calm the children down and meant that the medical or nursing procedures could be administered more smoothly. Most of them agreed that therapeutic play should be implemented within the hospital. Most importantly, nurses believe that it creates a more positive image of the hospital and staff as a result of implementing therapeutic play interventions for hospitalised children. Nevertheless, they expressed strong concern about the extra manpower required, which needs more support from the hospital organisation. However, the shortage of nurses in Hong Kong hospitals is not just a local but a global problem. Although most nurses believe that therapeutic play can be an effective intervention for promoting the psychological well-being of hospitalised children, it is not feasible for them to spend half an hour providing play activities for each child.
Nevertheless, supporting the children to adapt to life in the hospital and face the stress of treatments is crucial. It is essential to have Hospital Play Service in paediatric wards. Using hospital play specialists (HPS) to implement therapeutic play may be one of the best solutions to the shortage of nurses. Most hospitals in Australia, the United States, and other Western countries employ HPS, who play an important role in promoting psychological care for hospitalised children through the provision of play activities. Although it may require some extra resources in the short term, it would certainly enhance hospitals’ capacity to promote better health in the long run. Indeed, it only takes about half an hour a day to provide a creative recreational and psychosocial intervention to make a child’s hospitalisation less difficult. Clearly, it would be economically feasible for the healthcare system to consider and implement this intervention as a routine practice for hospitalised children.
34.19	Limitations 
There are some limitations of this study. First, although a randomised controlled trial is the most powerful approach for testing cause-and-effect relationships between independent and dependent variables, we could not randomise individual patients within a paediatric unit in a hospital because there was a possibility of contamination between different treatment groups within the setting, and because some children and their parents might have been concerned if they were aware that they were experiencing a different form of intervention. Therefore, a non-equivalent control group design was used. Second, the use of convenience sampling and therapeutic play intervention was only implemented in one setting, thus limiting the generalisability of the results. Third, this study only observed children’s anxiety levels and emotional responses on two consecutive days, which may not have been long enough to fully assess hospitalisation’s effect on the children’s psychological well-being. Nevertheless, as short-stay hospitalisation is recommended in today’s healthcare policy, many hospitalised children will be discharged home after 1 to 3 days.
34.20	Practice implications 
The findings of the study generate new knowledge and evidence about therapeutic play with major clinical implications. The results emphasise the importance of integrating therapeutic play as an essential component of holistic and high-quality care to ease the psychological burden of hospitalised children. It also promotes the awareness in healthcare professionals and parents that play is a very important part of children’s life, and that they need play even when they are ill. Indeed, play is instinctive, voluntary, and spontaneous; children play just as birds fly and fish swim. We believe the therapeutic play intervention can be applied to all children regardless of their cultural backgrounds or settings. Given the importance of play to children’s psychological health, it is recommended that the hospital authority should advocate the importance of play for hospitalised children by providing more resources to establish more space and facilitates for children to play. Most importantly, it is crucial to employ hospital play specialists to facilitate the integration of therapeutic play into routine care for hospitalised children. 
34.21	Conclusion
Notwithstanding the potential limitations, this study has addressed a gap in the literature by examining the effects of a therapeutic play intervention on the outcomes of hospitalised children. The most important contribution of this study is the empirical evidence it provides to support the effectiveness of therapeutic play intervention in minimising the anxiety and negative emotions of hospitalised children.
